Dan McKee delivers his annual State of the State address in the House Chamber of the Rhode Island State House Tuesday evening. PROVIDENCE, R.I. – Gov. Daniel McKee committed to raising the per capita income in Rhode Island in his annual State of the State address on Tuesday. Specifically, the goal is to raise per capita income by at least $20,000 by 2030. Rhode Island’s per capita income was about $43,000 in 2022, according to the most recent census data. “Just think how much housing insecurity and food insecurity we could address as a state if we double down and work to raise per capita income across Rhode Island, helping every family,” he said. Like with his education plan last year, McKee promised to release a detailed plan in the next 100 days to meet his per capita income goal while also highlighting work in other policy areas from last year that may already be contributing to that goal. For example, McKee emphasized the job creation opportunities from more state spending on items such as affordable housing, fixing the state’s roads and bridges, developing another offshore wind farm and increasing tourism to the state. In these areas, McKee proposed both new funding in the state budget, such as $5 million to help municipalities expedite infrastructure projects, and two new bond referendums, a $100 million housing production bond and a bond to fund the construction of a new State Archive and History Center. Another example McKee cited was the State Institute for Cybersecurity and Emerging Technologies, which former Congressman Jim Langevin and Rhode Island College President Jack Warner launched last year, promising to help students break into a lucrative industry. This year, McKee suggested putting a cybersecurity bond before voters to grow the program, and set a goal of enrolling 1,000 students in the next five years. The per capita income goal mirrors a similar pledge from last year to boost key metrics of the state’s education – standardized test scores, attendance rates and Free Application for Federal Student Aid completion – to Massachusetts levels by 2030. McKee commended the team who’s been working on those efforts since then, including Education Commissioner Angelica Infante-Green and former National Education Association of Rhode Island Executive Director Bob Walsh, who now heads the nonprofit Always Learning Rhode Island. Though the administration has been working on all three of those metrics, last year saw a strong focus on attendance in particular, something school districts nationwide have struggled with since the pandemic. Statewide absence has hovered between 8,000 and 15,000 students daily since the start of this school year, according to the state’s data tools that were launched as part of the improvement plan. McKee recognized two Providence students, second-grade Alejandro Uz and high school junior Isabella Vasquez, who improved their attendance in the last year. “We know that students who attend school regularly perform, on average, about 20 points better on reading and math than those who are chronically absent – that’s why attendance matters,” he said. McKee promised to continue funding education support, including a new $15 million line item this year for math and English coaching for students and professional development for teachers, but he also called on families to “join the team” to improve education outcomes. “Every home, every day, learning matters,” he said. Just as McKee echoed promises from last year on education, House Minority Leader Mike Chippendale reprised Republican calls to give parents more choice in where to send their children to school in his State of the State response. “We support parents who are no longer accepting that their children’s futures must be invested in the same broken systems,” he said. “Parents and students alike want to receive a quality education and we’re obligated to respect and support the wishes of those parents by providing the options to best educate their children.” Strengthening the state’s health care system also made the list of top priorities this year, specifically making improvements to the state’s hospitals. In addition to another round of direct payments to hospitals, McKee proposed $135 million to increase health care provider rates and support behavioral health services, as well as funding to bring rate increases for early intervention up to levels recommended by the Office of the Health Insurance Commissioner. He also teased an executive order that will create a working group focused on health care improvement. Chippendale also singled out health care as a high-priority area. “Rhode Island’s health care system is sadly collapsing,” he said. “We’re hemorrhaging practitioners of every discipline, from specialists to support positions. Providers are retiring at an ever-increasing rate or fleeing our state altogether while most graduates are not even looking for health care jobs here in Rhode Island.” He called for the General Assembly to pass legislation to incentivize medical graduates to stay in Rhode Island, adjust the Medicaid reimbursement rate and reinstitute access to telemedicine across state lines. McKee championed the new State Health Lab, which began construction last year, as benefiting both health care in Rhode Island and as another facet of his plan to increase incomes. With a push from House Speaker Joseph Shekarchi, last year’s budget included the creation of a new quasi-public agency and $45 million for that new agency to support the development of the life science sector in the state. “For over a decade, Rhode Islanders have stepped up to the microphone and talked about how Massachusetts is a leader in life science and that Rhode Island could be as well,” McKee said. “Instead of dreaming of that possibility, thanks to the leadership of Speaker Shekarchi, we’re making it a reality.” In a speech that foreshadowed big asks from voters on the 2024 ballot, McKee struck a tone of teamwork, interweaving references to his time as a coach of the Rhode Island Shooting Stars basketball team. “They were an example of a team who helped each other do their very best,” he said. “In many ways, their story is Rhode Island’s story too. In 2024, Team Rhode Island will continue using our skills to make our state one of the very best in the nation. Valueland, which was located in Johnston at 1386 Atwood Ave., was a local supermarket chain that advertised themselves as a low-cost supermarket. The food market is now a Burlington Coat Factory. After two decades in business, the store closed in 1994, due in large part to increased competition from larger supermarkets such as Stop and Shop. The reunion was organized by Jennifer Cipalone. The reunion, however, was the first time in a long time that she had seen so many fellow former coworkers in the same place. “This feels like a wedding in the family,” Cipalone said. “It’s so nice to see everyone reconnecting, and continue the special friendships we’ve had, and that’s why I wanted to get everyone together, especially with the way the world is now.” The process of getting everyone back together, Cipalone said, was relatively easy. The only real challenge was looking up female coworkers who had since married, but she was still able to track them down using their maiden names. Though life had changed for those who got together again, the nature of the evening resulted in plenty of reminiscing. Cipalone said that while she was at first worried about low attendance, hosting the event and seeing a room filled with old faces was incredibly rewarding. “It’s a typical Rhode Island story — everybody knows somebody, and that’s how the word got out,” Cipalone said. “We had a wonderful turnout, and we’re going to do it again.” After more than 30 years apart, no one was in a rush to leave.
